leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 1 r 1] r 1 Name of rules

p.text: These rules may be cited as the District Court Rules 1973 .
These rules shall commence on the commencement of the Act.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 1 r 6] r 6 Seal of the Court

p.text: The registrar is to seal or stamp the following documents (or cause the documents to be sealed or stamped) with the seal of the Court:
any order, notice, warrant, certificate, judgment or process made, given or issued by the registrar (or any copy of such a document),
any other document issued by the registrar that is required by the rules to be sealed.
Without limiting subrule (1), a document may be stamped with the seal of the Court by any of the following means:
affixing the seal on the document by means of a rubber stamp,
affixing an adhesive label on the document with a representation of the seal printed on it,
printing a representation of the seal on the document by electronic or mechanical means.
[r 6 subst Gaz 143 of 21 September 2001 p 7899]

A convenient summary of the history of court seals in New South Wales is set out in Saffron v Delaney (1953) 53 SR (NSW) 80 . It has been held in relation to a bankruptcy notice that signing and stamping was essential to the validity of the notice: Re O'Sullivan; Ex parte Bank of New Zealand (1991) 30 FCR 112; 102 ALR 206 . It is arguable that sealing of the documents set out in r 6 is also essential for their validity.
